ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained knowledge and insights in various big ethical and methodological questions regarding translation, including domestication vs. foreignization, the usage of footnotes, the role of clarification, translation of vernacular languages, etc. Also, I gained more insight into the business and commercial side of translation, regarding practices and issues in publishing, the selection of translators, and how translations are chosen. I also learned to write about translators themselves and to explore the relationships between translators and the authors they translate.

We studied theoretical texts on english to french and french to english literary translation. We talked about the ethical implications of translating to and from different languages, of the identity of a translator in relation to the author/text they translate, and more.
This course focused on the study and practice of translation; as a result, I was able to work on both on my knowledge of various strategies for translation and develop my own skills as a translator.
I learned so much about the theory and practice of translation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: great survey of topics to discuss and texts to translate, small class size allows for everyone to have a chance to translate, interesting midterm and final project topics, consistent and useful feedback from Prof. Kaplan and Jeanne, seeing primary documents at the Beinecke and getting guest lectures from people actually working in the translation field put the theory in practice 

Areas of improvement: I'd actually enjoy having more translations as assignments instead of just readings so that students have more time to sit with the text they are translating and also have chances to peer review or edit translations with classmates; I enjoyed the readings but I would've also enjoyed more hands-on practice outside of the atelier each class

Strengths: Profs. Kaplan and Sauvage are extremely knowledgeable and passionate about their work. They clearly loved teaching this course and made an effort to get to know all of their students well. The course is well-organized, with each week focusing on a different ethical or theoretical aspect of translation. The texts are really interesting and vary in form. I also really enjoyed the in-class translation workshops.

The only weakness is that sometimes the presentations got in the way of actually discussing the texts as a class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Professor Kaplan is a great professor, translator, and author. She is so kind, I highly recommend taking this course and learning from her (and Jeanne). I really enjoyed that it was co-taught!

I would absolutely recommend this course to any student who is interested in translating! I've rarely had chances to discuss a lot of the big, and potentially unanswerable questions regarding translation, so it was really helpful to hear about different solutions and perspectives my classmates and instructors had toward questions of translating dialect in an ethical way or learning how to balance interpretation and translation. While previous translation courses I've taken focused a lot more on the actual practice of translation, I felt this theoretical and methodological course was needed to justify and understand the logic behind the choices I was making in my translations.

Absolutely! If you are comfortable speaking French and have experience or are interested in literary translation, this is the class for you. I will say, though, you might better appreciate the syllabus if you already have some foundation in translation theory, like FREN 191.
I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in working on their translation skills while developing their knowledge of French literature.
Yes! The workshops were fascinating and the professors were wonderful.
